channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Audio Offers Gruesome Details of Jamal Khashoggi Killing, Turkish Official Says
item.media:description: Turkish forensic and investigation officers at the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul on Wednesday.
item.description: The Saudi journalist’s fingers were severed and he was later beheaded, according to details from audio recordings published in the Turkish media.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: In Afghanistan’s Season of Crisis, ‘Words Do Not Have the Strength’
item.media:description: An Afghan soldier inspected a traveler at a highway checkpoint in August. After 17 years, the war’s daily toll has soared, often reaching 100 dead.
item.description: Seventeen years into the war, Afghans cannot remember a time quite like this, with peril and hopelessness at every turn, and no clear way out.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Brazil’s Bitter Presidential Race Leads to Scores of Assaults
item.media:description: Fernanda Villas Bôas, a journalist who was attacked by supporters of Brazil’s far-right presidential candidate, Jair Bolsonaro, believes he has encouraged both sides to act violently.
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.description: The country is divided between a far-right candidate who advocates fighting violence with violence, and a leftist rival. The increasing animosity has led to more than 70 attacks on political opponents.
item.dc:creator: MANUELA ANDREONI

item.title: Theresa May Plays for Time on Brexit, Amid Talk of an Extension
item.media:description: British Prime Minister Theresa May sought more time in deadlocked talks over her country’s exit from the European Union.
item.description: At a summit Mrs. May asked for help in reviving stalled exit talks, but offered little new. Negotiations now look likely to go down to the wire.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Japan’s Cherry Blossoms (Some of Them) Appear Months Early
item.media:description: A cherry blossom in Tokyo on Thursday.
item.description: An unusually strong typhoon season may have caused the famously picturesque flowers to bloom long before April, when they typically emerge.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: U.S. Spy Agencies Are Increasingly Convinced of Saudi Prince’s Ties to Journalist’s Disappearance
item.media:description: Mr. Pompeo met with the Saudi foreign minister, Adel al-Jubeir, in Riyadh on Tuesday.
item.description: American intelligence officials have growing circumstantial evidence of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman’s involvement in Jamal Khashoggi’s disappearance in Istanbul.
item.dc:creator: JULIAN E. BARNES, MATTHEW ROSENBERG and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Legalizing Recreational Marijuana, Canada Begins a National Experiment
item.media:description: People gathered in Toronto to watch the “bud drop” at the stroke of midnight, in celebration of the legalization on Wednesday of recreational cannabis use in Canada.
item.description: On Wednesday, Canada becomes the first major world economy to legalize recreational marijuana, presenting the country with enormous public policy challenges.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Afghan Leader Blindsided by U.S. Meeting With Taliban, Officials Say
item.media:description: American forces in Helmand Province, Afghanistan, last year. American diplomats have quietly met with Taliban representatives in recent months, excluding the Afghan government.
item.description: An American envoy who met the Taliban reportedly tried to evade the topic during a meeting with an already concerned Afghan president, several officials say.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: The Interpreter: How One Journalist’s Death Provoked a Backlash That Thousands Dead in Yemen Did Not
item.media:description: The Saudi-led war in Yemen has become one of the worst humanitarian disasters in years.
item.description: The sudden turn against Saudi Arabia reveals uncomfortable realities of alliance politics, group psychology and the perception of morality.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: Canada’s New Marijuana Economy: Meet the Winners and Losers
item.description: After 95 years of prohibition, Canada has legalized marijuana. We met with buyers, sellers, growers and students to hear what they had to say.

item.title: Saudi Journalist, Midterms, DNA: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: U.S. Bars American Aid Groups From Traveling to North Korea
item.media:description: A farm field in North Korea, whose citizens grapple with food shortages. The travel ban affects humanitarian efforts to provide farming assistance.
item.description: The move comes as the Trump administration seeks to tighten sanctions as part of its maximum-pressure campaign during nuclear negotiations.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Overlooked No More: Yamei Kin, the Chinese Doctor Who Introduced Tofu to the West
item.media:description: Yamei Kin, a Chinese-born doctor, was enlisted by the United States government to study the soybean and how it could be used in America.
item.description: Long before veggie burgers and soy lattes were fashionable, Kin was sent on a mission by the United States government to uncover the benefits of the soybean to Americans.

item.title: The Skywhale Returns to Australia’s Skies, and Its Creator Braces for Impact
item.media:description: The Skywhale hot air balloon flying over Yarra Glen in Yarra Valley, Australia, this month.
item.description: The buxom hot-air balloon was widely condemned when it first appeared five years ago. The artist who created it is hoping for a warmer reception this time.
item.dc:creator: CLARISSA SEBAG-MONTEFIORE

item.title: Ebola Outbreak in Congo Not a Global Emergency, W.H.O. Says
item.media:description: A health worker sprays disinfectant on his colleague after working at an Ebola treatment center in Beni, Congo.
item.description: Health officials expressed serious concern about the disease, which has a high risk of spreading to neighbors, but were optimistic it would be controlled.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: U.N. Syria Envoy, Staffan de Mistura, Announces Resignation
item.media:description: Staffan de Mistura, the United Nations special envoy for Syria, said he would step down at the end of November.
item.description: Mr. de Mistura, the United Nations chief negotiator for Syria, will be the third diplomat to leave the job since Syria’s grinding civil war began 7 years ago.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: The Legal Cannabis Experiment Begins: The Canada Letter
item.media:description: The Natural Vibe store in St. John’s, Newfoundland, on Wednesday after legal recreational marijuana went on sale.
item.description: A special edition of the Canada Letter looks at the day marijuana became legal.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: A Top Indian Minister Resigns, but Can #MeToo Reform Government?
item.media:description: A demonstration in New Delhi on Monday against M.J. Akbar, the minister of state for external affairs. He said he had resigned to fight allegations of sexual harassment.
item.description: India’s governing party promised to champion women and economic growth, but more women are leaving the work force than ever, partly over safety concerns.
item.dc:creator: MARIA ABI-HABIB and VINDU GOEL

item.title: Istanbul Vending Machines Offer Subway Credit for Recycled Bottles and Cans
item.media:description: The new Istanbul subway machines, which will add credit to subway cards and crush, shred and sort recycled material.
item.description: The city has installed “reverse vending machines” at metro stations that crush, shred and sort the materials as a way of paying for travel.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Queensland Becomes Latest Australian State to Decriminalize Abortion
item.media:description: A rally in support of proposed changes to Queensland’s abortion laws in Brisbane, Australia, on Sunday.
item.description: After days of emotional debate, lawmakers overturned an 1899 law that made abortion a criminal offense. “History has been made,” the premier said.
item.dc:creator: RICK ROJAS

item.title: Mother Mushroom, Vietnamese Activist, Is Said to Be Released
item.media:description: Nguyen Ngoc Nhu Quynh, center, in court in Vietnam last year. Also known as the blogger Mother Mushroom, she was arrested in 2016 and accused of “conducting propaganda against the state.”
item.description: The blogger, whose real name is Nguyen Ngoc Nhu Quynh, was freed to fly to the U.S. as Defense Secretary Jim Mattis was visiting, rights groups said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: China Imposes Record Fine on Vaccine Maker Over Safety Scandal
item.media:description: Chinese officials checking rabies vaccines at a government facility in Huaibei in July. On Tuesday, Chinese regulators fined a maker of faulty rabies shots more than $1.3 billion.
item.description: The penalty, of $1.3 billion, comes at a time of increasing anxieties among the country’s middle class, already furious about a spate of drug and food safety scandals.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE

item.title: Student Gunman Kills 19 and Wounds Dozens at a College in Crimea
item.media:description: Emergency workers loading an injured person into an ambulance on Wednesday in Kerch, eastern Crimea.
item.media:credit: Kerch Fm, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The lone attacker detonated an explosive device, then opened fire at his classmates, in the deadliest school assault in Russia since the Beslan massacre in 2004.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Mike Pompeo Meets Turkish President to Discuss Saudi Journalist’s Fate
item.media:description: Turkish news outlets reported having heard audio recordings from inside the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul made when the journalist Jamal Khashoggi met his end.
item.description: President Trump said the United States had asked Turkish officials for what they say are recordings of the gruesome killing of Jamal Khashoggi by Saudi agents.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: What’s at Stake in Brazil’s Election? The Future of the Amazon
item.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro at a rally in Brasília, the capital. The second and final round of the presidential election is Oct. 28.
item.description: The next president of Brazil may shape the destiny of the Amazon, which is vital to reining in climate change. The stakes for the planet are huge.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Ian Kiernan, Australian Sailor Who Battled Pollution, Dies at 78
item.media:description: Ian B.C. Kiernan in 1995, the year he was awarded the Medal of the Order of Australia.
item.description: Appalled by the trash he saw in the world’s oceans, he began a cleanup campaign in Sydney that went global.
item.dc:creator: LIVIA ALBECK-RIPKA

item.title: Israel Strikes Gaza After a Rocket Is Fired
item.media:description: Smoke billowed from the Gaza city of Rafah on Wednesday after an Israeli airstrike.
item.description: The main militant groups in Gaza, including Hamas and Islamic Jihad, issued a joint statement denying responsibility for the rocket fire against Israel.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: South Korea Denies Refugee Status to Hundreds of Fleeing Yemenis
item.media:description: Anti-refugee protesters in Jeju City, South Korea, in June.
item.media:credit: Jun Michael Park for The New York Times
item.description: The arrival of the refugees from the war-torn country ignited a backlash in South Korea, fueling the country’s first anti-asylum movement.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Saudi Arabia Delivers $100 Million Pledged to U.S. as Pompeo Lands in Riyadh
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo met Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman in Riyadh on Tuesday.
item.description: The funds, earmarked for aid to Syria, arrived as Secretary of State Mike Pompeo visited the kingdom to discuss the fate of a missing Saudi dissident.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: A K.K.K. Endorsement? No Thanks, Says Brazil’s Top Presidential Candidate
item.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro, the far-right front-runner in Brazil’s presidential race, rejected an endorsement from David Duke, the former grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan.
item.description: “He sounds like us,” David Duke, a former grand wizard, said of Jair Bolsonaro, the far-right candidate. “Enormous stupidity!” Mr. Bolsonaro responded.
item.dc:creator: SHASTA DARLINGTON

item.title: The Jamal Khashoggi Case: Suspects Had Ties to Saudi Crown Prince
item.media:description: A still from a security-camera video shows a jet that Turkish authorities say carried some of the Saudi agents involved in the disappearance of Jamal Khashoggi.
item.media:credit: Sabah, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Links between Prince Mohammed and at least four suspects in the disappearance of Jamal Khashoggi may make it harder to advance a “rogue killers” explanation.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK, MALACHY BROWNE, BEN HUBBARD and DAVID BOTTI

item.title: Pompeo, Politics, Charlottesville: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: U.S. Military Airstrike Kills 60 Shabab Fighters in Somalia
item.media:description: Somali soldiers patrolling at a military base shortly after an American soldier was killed in June. The Shabab, Al Qaeda’s affiliate in East Africa, have proved resilient.
item.description: The military said the strike, which followed attacks on Somali security forces and their American advisers, was the deadliest against the extremist group in nearly a year.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Books News: Anna Burns Wins the Man Booker Prize for ‘Milkman’
item.media:description: Anna Burns’s “Milkman” is the winner of the 2018 Man Booker Prize.
item.description: The judges cited her use of dark humor to explore tribalism, state-sponsored terrorism, social division and sexual and political oppression.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA ALTER

item.title: At War: We Want to Hear Your Family’s Stories From World War I
item.media:description: A photo of President Harry Truman and his unit during World War I.
item.media:credit: Shawn Brackbill for The New York Times
item.description: We’re asking readers to tell us about their family members who served during World War I.

item.title: Migrant Caravan Enters Guatemala From Honduras
item.description: Up to 2,000 migrants passed through police roadblocks and crossed into Guatemala. President Trump has threatened to cut off aid to Honduras if it did not try to stop the caravan.

item.title: Embattled Macron Shuffles French Cabinet, Again, in Favor of Loyalists
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France and his new interior minister, Christophe Castaner, right. Mr. Castaner once declared “an aspect of love” in his relationship with Mr. Macron.
item.description: The French president chose Christophe Castaner, who once declared “an aspect of love” in their relationship, to take over the Interior Ministry.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: We’re Covering Heritage Sites Threatened by Climate Change. The List Just Got Longer.
item.media:description: Cedars grow sparsely in the mountains near Jaj, Lebanon.
item.description: A new study says some of the most important ancient places in the Mediterranean might not survive global warming.
item.dc:creator: KENDRA PIERRE-LOUIS
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: Marijuana Legalization in Canada Has Companies Chasing a Green Rush
item.media:description: An employee tending marijuana plants at Canopy Growth’s Tweed factory last month in Smiths Falls, Ontario.
item.media:credit: Dave Chan for The New York Times
item.description: The decision by Canada to become the first major economy to fully legalize marijuana this month has created a new, multibillion dollar industry.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Google to Charge Phone Makers for Android Apps in Europe
item.media:description: Samsung unveiled its Galaxy Note 9 handset in Brooklyn in August. The device is one of 24,000 that use Google’s Android operating system.
item.media:credit: Timothy A. Clary/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: To comply with a European antitrust ruling, Google will begin charging a licensing fee of handset makers.
item.dc:creator: ADAM SATARIANO

item.title: Trump Threatens to Punish Honduras Over Immigrant Caravan
item.media:description: Moving on foot and in vehicles, the migrants crossed into Guatemala on Monday, pushed past two police roadblocks and came to a rest for the night in the town of Esquipulas.
item.description: More than 1,500 mostly Honduran migrants are in Guatemala, heading to the United States. President Trump has warned Honduras he might cut aid if the migrants do not return home.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Saudis Issued Dire Warnings Against U.S. Sanctions. But How Much Leverage Do They Have?
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia in Riyadh on Tuesday.
item.description: The Saudis have a powerful tool in their ability to raise oil prices but are loath to use it. And they could not easily switch to China or Russia for defense.
item.dc:creator: CLIFFORD KRAUSS and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Saudi Crown Prince to Pompeo: We Are ‘Allies’
item.description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo met with Crown Prince Mohammad bin Salman to discuss the disappearance of the Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

item.title: British Hoarders Stock Up on Supplies, Preparing for Brexit
item.media:description: Nevine and Richard Mann have started planting crops in their garden in Cornwall, England, in case Britain’s departure from the European Union disrupts food supplies.
item.media:credit: James Beck for The New York Times
item.description: Some people are warning of possible food rationing, medicine shortages and civil disorder if no deal is struck with the European Union. Brexit supporters call that fear-mongering.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Canada is Legalizing Marijuana. Here Are Some Questions, Answered.
item.media:description: This year’s annual marijuana rally on Parliament Hill in Ottawa, Ontario.
item.description: As Canada prepares to become only the second country in the world, besides Uruguay, to legalize marijuana, the country is scrambling to get ready.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN, CATHERINE PORTER and DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Trump Jumps to the Defense of Saudi Arabia in Khashoggi Case
item.media:description: Protesters holding pictures of the missing journalist Jamal Khashoggi outside the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul this month.
item.description: President Trump accused Saudi Arabia’s critics of presuming guilt, as Secretary of State Mike Pompeo met with Saudi leaders in Riyadh to help defuse a crisis.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD, RICK GLADSTONE and MARK LANDLER

item.title: Talks Begin on Disarming Korean Border Village
item.media:description: Ri Son-gwon, the North Korean official in charge of unification, crossing the border in the truce village of Panmunjom on Monday to attend a meeting with Cho Myoung-gyon, his South Korean counterpart.
item.description: The United Nations Command and representatives from both Koreas will discuss erasing the demarcation line at Panmunjom, officials said, as a way to improve ties.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: 2 Myanmar Fighter Jets Crash, Killing Pilots and an 11-Year-Old
item.media:description: The wreckage of a Myanmar Air Force F-7 fighter jet after it crashed near the city of Saklu on Tuesday.
item.description: It was the latest in a string of accidents for one of Asia’s largest militaries, which has rapidly expanded its arsenal.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH and SAW NANG
